title: Ketan Patel

fields.name: Ketan Patel
fields.known_for: Co-founder and CEO of Greater Pacific Capital; founder and chair of the Force for Good Initiative; lead of a UNCTAD-hosted Future Capital working group on the future of finance
fields.alma_mater: London School of Economics; City University Business School (MBA)
fields.organization: Greater Pacific Capital; Force for Good Initiative

lead:
'''Ketan Patel''' (born February 1962) is a British investor, strategist and author.<ref name="R186" /> He is the chief executive and co-founder of the private equity firm ''Greater Pacific Capital'' (GPC) and the founder and chairman of the Force for Good Initiative, which publishes research on capital allocation, technology and sustainable development.<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R187" /><ref name="R188" /><ref name="R180" />

Patel was a managing director at Goldman Sachs, where he founded and led the bank's Strategic Group.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R211" /><ref name="R212" /> He previously served as a partner at KPMG, leading its European strategy consultancy and serving on the firm's board and European strategy team.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R62" /><ref name="R212" />

Patel is the author of ''The Master Strategist'' (2005).<ref name="R216" /><ref name="R181" /> His published work addresses system-level transitions in geopolitics, technology and development in outlets including ''Frontiers'' journals, ''Cadmus'' and Reuters.<ref name="R174" /><ref name="R197" /><ref name="R161" /><ref name="R188" /><ref name="R189" />

''The Master Strategist'' has been reviewed in ''Business Standard'' and ''IMFO'' and carried an endorsement quotation attributed to Nelson Mandela.<ref name="R210" /><ref name="R185" /><ref name="R218" />

sections.heading: Early life and education
sections.wikitext: Patel was born in February 1962 and grew up in London.<ref name="R186" /><ref name="R220" /> He graduated with a BSc in Economics from the London School of Economics and completed an MBA at City University Business School.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R62" /> He holds the ACMA qualification and a postgraduate degree in neuroscience from King's College London.<ref name="R62" />

sections.heading: Career
sections.wikitext:
===Hewlett-Packard and KPMG===
Patel worked at Hewlett-Packard and later joined KPMG.<ref name="R207" /> At KPMG he led the firm's European strategy consultancy, became a partner, and served on the firm's board and European strategy team.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R62" /><ref name="R207" />

===Goldman Sachs===
Patel was a managing director in Goldman Sachs' investment banking division, where he founded and led the bank's Strategic Group.<ref name="R220" /><ref name="R58" /><ref name="R211" /><ref name="R212" /> In 2003, ''The Globe and Mail'' referred to him as Goldman Sachs' “chief futurologist”.<ref name="R220" /> He said the group's role was to show clients "how to leapfrog the world, not catch up".<ref name="R220" />

===Greater Pacific Capital===
In 2005, Patel left Goldman Sachs and co-founded the London-based private equity firm Greater Pacific Capital, where he serves as chief executive.<ref name="R147" /><ref name="R187" /><ref name="R211" /><ref name="R221" /> In 2007, the ''Financial Times'' reported that Greater Pacific Capital was bidding jointly with Torrent Pharmaceuticals for Merck's generics business, a transaction described as a US$5 billion deal.<ref name="R223" /> Greater Pacific Capital has also been reported as advising Apollo Tyres on its proposed US$2.5 billion acquisition of Cooper Tire & Rubber Co in 2013, and in 2018 the U.S. Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) committed US$125 million to one of the firm's funds.<ref name="R204" /><ref name="R202" />

===Force for Good Initiative===
Patel founded and chairs the Force for Good Initiative, which publishes research on investment, technology and policy approaches to sustainable development.<ref name="R187" /><ref name="R179" /><ref name="R180" /> Its report series includes ''Capital as a Force for Good'' and ''Technology as a Force for Good''.<ref name="R178" /><ref name="R179" /><ref name="R180" /> In a 2024 Reuters commentary, Patel described the ''Capital as a Force for Good'' report as identifying scalable, existing initiatives intended to accelerate progress toward the Sustainable Development Goals.<ref name="R189" /> In 2025, Force for Good published ''The World Investment Plan''; Club de Madrid described the report as proposing a US$125 trillion investment plan through 2035 and quoted Patel as the initiative's chairman.<ref name="R215" /><ref name="R219" /> A UNFCCC COP30 dialogues report listed Patel as a panelist as chair of Force for Good, and one session referenced an investment plan developed by the initiative.<ref name="R214" />

===Institutional and advisory roles===
Patel serves as a trustee and executive director of the World Academy of Art and Science and has published in its journal ''Cadmus''.<ref name="R176" /><ref name="R161" /> He serves on the advisory board of the UN Business and Human Security Initiative at the London School of Economics and Political Science.<ref name="R193" /> In 2019, he was asked to define and lead the finance working group for the UN-hosted Future Capital initiative, co-hosted by UN Trade and Development (UNCTAD), the UN Office for Partnerships and the World Academy of Art and Science.<ref name="R195" /> He is also a member of the Jane Goodall Legacy Foundation's Council for Hope.<ref name="R213" />

sections.heading: Public speaking and media
sections.wikitext: Patel has participated in panels and interviews on geopolitics, technology, capital allocation and sustainable development.<ref name="R172" /><ref name="R222" /><ref name="R224" /><ref name="R225" /> He has appeared on ''SALT Talks'' and moderated a research-summit panel at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) focused on technology, artificial intelligence and sustainability.<ref name="R172" /><ref name="R222" /> He has also been listed as a speaker at the Science and Technology in Society (STS) Forum in Kyoto, and participated in a Doha Forum panel discussion held in partnership with the Qatar Free Zones Authority.<ref name="R224" /><ref name="R225" /> He has participated in UNFCCC COP30 dialogues as chair of Force for Good.<ref name="R214" />

sections.heading: Ideas and contributions
sections.wikitext:
Patel's published work addresses systemic transition and systemic risk in the international order, with emphasis on the interaction of geopolitics, technology and capital allocation.

===Great-power transitions and the international order===
In 2025, Patel and co-authors argued in ''Frontiers in Political Science'' that major powers tend to pass through identifiable life-cycle phases, and they assessed implications for U.S. strategic positioning and alliance structures.<ref name="R174" />

===Capital allocation and development finance===
In a 2025 ''Cadmus'' article, Patel and co-authors argued that progress toward the UN Sustainable Development Goals is constrained less by the absolute availability of capital than by allocation mechanisms, incentives and risk pricing.<ref name="R161" /> In a 2024 Reuters commentary, he argued that closing development gaps depends primarily on scaling proven solutions, with finance mobilization following once implementation pathways are clear.<ref name="R189" />

===Climate policy pathways===
In 2024, Patel and co-author Chris Hansmeyer assessed COP28's outcomes against the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways used in climate scenario analysis, and outlined five potential scenarios for climate-transition progress.<ref name="R197" />

===Information-era security and "cognitive empires"===
A 2025 SSRN preprint by Patel set out the concept of "cognitive empires", arguing that algorithmic systems can shift power projection toward influence over attention and decision-making, with implications for agency, sovereignty and security.<ref name="R177" />

===India's digital public infrastructure===
In 2023, Patel told ''The Sydney Morning Herald'' that “This will be India’s century” and described India's digital identity and payments infrastructure as enabling large-scale financial inclusion and lowering transaction frictions across the economy.<ref name="R221" />

sections.heading: Influence and reception
sections.wikitext: A 2025 review of ''The Master Strategist'' in ''Business Standard'' discussed Patel's approach to strategy and his use of purpose and principle as organising concepts.<ref name="R210" /> An additional review appeared in the ''IMFO'' journal (Institute of Municipal Finance Officers).<ref name="R218" /> An endorsement quotation attributed to Nelson Mandela has appeared on editions of the book.<ref name="R185" /> In a 2003 profile of Patel's work at Goldman Sachs, ''The Globe and Mail'' noted that the accuracy of strategic forecasts is difficult to verify and that clients may treat such outlooks as confidential tools.<ref name="R220" />

sections.heading: Personal life
sections.wikitext: Patel lives in London and has cited meditation and long-distance running among his interests.<ref name="R58" />
